did.abstract: Collection consists of letters between the Boardman family. The earliest letters are between Volney and his daughter Margaret, who was attending an academy between 1850 and 1860; they concern her education and the family's financial hardship following a drought and failed crops. Civil War letters of James L. Boardman, 5th Alabama Regiment, C.S.A., and of his brother, Henry, 62nd Alabama Regiment, C.S.A., describe camp life, supplies, capture and imprisonment by the Yankees, military campaigns, and the destruction of the Harper's Ferry and Winchester Railroad. Letters following the war largely detail family affairs, with one letter mentioning the activities of the Ku Klux Klan.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Confederate family, from Hale County, Ala. Volney Boardman (b. 1810) was a silversmith, jeweler, and circuit clerk who joined the Democratic Party at thet start of the Civil War. He was married twice: to Margaret Locke and Harriett Earle Harrison. Volney and Margaret had two children, James Locke and Margaret E. Boardman; Volney and Harriett had six children, including Henry and Laura (both correspondents in the collection).
